Praeterea quaeri solet Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 6, c. 1 (I, 89, ll. 4). . This is the sixth distinction, which is a continuation of the preceding. For after the Master determined about divine generation with respect to the thing generating and the thing generated, now he begins to treat this matter with respect to the mode of generation, and this is divided into three parts. For in the first place he proposes the question, in the second place he offers a solution, and in the third place he explains the declaration of the response. The second begins at
nec voluntate nec necessitate Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 6, c. 1 (I, 89, ll. 6). . The third begins at
praedicta tamen verba Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 6, c. 1 (I, 90, ll. 24). .

The second is divided into two parts because in the first place regarding the solution he puts his intention, in the second place he introduces and solves an objection. The second begins at
sed contra hoc opponitur Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 6, c. 1 (I, 90, ll. 6). .

The third is also divided into two parts. For in the first place regarding the declaration he puts forward his intention, in the second place he concludes that the declaration is true. The second begins at
dicamus ergo Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 6, c. 1 (I, 91, ll. 1).
. etc.
Regarding this distinction it is asked whether the fecund memory of the Father willing and freely determined to beget the Son who is the second person.

That not because the Father produces naturally, therefore not freely. The consequence holds and the antecedent is proved through Damascene in book one, chapter eight saying
generation is a work of nature Iohannes Damascenus, De Fide Orthodoxa, I, 8 (PL XXX). .

In the second place, it follows that the generation of the Son would be an operation of the will. The consequent seems false because it is an act of the memory of the Father. The consequence is clear because complacence or to please is an act of the will according to
Anselm in De Conceptu Virginali, in chapter two Anselmus, De Conceptu Virginali, 3 (II, 143, ll. 16-21) . This is confirmed because the act of the eternal supposite is an essential act, therefore no more determined to begetting the Son than the Son is determined to this, therefore. The conclusion is false, the consequences valid, and the antecedent apparent because every internal act of the Father is an immanent act and therefore essential and common to the whole.

In the third place, The Father is determined for begetting the Son in no way, therefore. The antecedent is proved because to be determined indicates an imperfection, therefore it should not be attributed to the Father or any other divine supposite. The proof of the antecedent is because for something to be determined by something is effectively to have been produced by that, or produced, or at least moved.

In opposition, there is the position of
Augustine IX De Trinitate, chapter 8 ,
the Word is conceived in love Augustinus, De Trinitate, IX, c. 8 (XXX) . With respect to the same position there is position of
the Master at the end of this sixth distinction Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 6, c. 1 (I, 91, ll. 3-6). , where lays out the position of
Augustine in Super Epistolam ad Ephesios Augustine, XXX . This is confirmed by reason in the following way: the eternal generation of the word is the most perfect operation, there it is a pleasing and free operation. The consequences holds because according to the
Philosopher in book II and X of the Ethics Aristotles, Ethics, X (1174b31-33) , the most perfect operation is the most pleasant. The antecedent is proved because in whatever degree the produced term is of a greater perfection, the operation or production is more perfect in the same degree. But the Son in the divine is of an infinite perfection, therefore also his production. But for this the Father is not undetermined, therefore he is determined

The first conclusion: though the infallible Word is beget immutably with the necessity of exigence, nevertheless without perfection the Father generates it with delight and for the sake of pleasure. The first part is proved because the same thing which is pure act necessarily drives forward such that it exists in three supposits. But these three things would not be unless the Father were to generate the Son, and the Father and the Son spirated the Holy Spirit. Therefore, from the necessity of natural exigence, The Son is beget from the Father. And this is confirmed because the Father is not able not to beget the Word, therefore he necessarily generates it.

The first corollary: though the Father begets with the necessity of exigence, nevertheless this necessity excludes both the necessity of co-action or indigence. The first part is clear through the conclusion. The second is clear because contra
Aureolum Aureoli, XXX
omnipotence is not able to be compelled.

The second corollary: just as it is repugnant that the Holy Spirit is not spirated from the Word, so necessarily essential love concurs for the generation of the Word. This is clear through the second part of the conclusion, which is proved through
Richard, De Trinitate, in the sixth book, in chapter 17,
who says
ingenitum velle de se habere conformem atque condignum idem videtur mihi quod gignere Richardus de Sancto Victore, De Trinitate, VI, c. 17 (252, ll. 52-53) .
To the same
Dionysius in his book On the Divine Names
says
amor divinus non dimisit Deum esse sine gignitione germinis. Pseudo-Dionysius, De divinis nominibus, c. 4 (XXX)
Whence
Matthew in chapter,
Here is my beloved son with whom I am well Matthaeus 3:17
etc.

The third corollary: the Father, or the fecundity of paternal memory, in no way, after he has produced the Word, was able or wished to produce the Word. This is clear because otherwise he would have generated it with the antecedent will, in opposition to
Augustine ad Orosium, quaestionem 8 Augustinus, Ad Orosium, XXX , and against
the Master in his text Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 6, c. 1 (I, 89-91). . Again, then there would be a priority in the divine, which is against what was said in
another question Cross-Reference, XXX .

The second conclusion: just as it is repugnant that the paternal memory produced a fallible word from eternity, so it is repugnant that every aeternal act is or was notional. The first part is clear through what was said in
another conclusion Cross-Reference
Nevertheless this is confirmed because it is repugnant that something fallible exists but is not measured by time. Therefore no such thing was able to be produced without time. The second part is proved because the act of predestination of Peter or another is an eternal act and is not notional, indeed it is common to three persons, therefore.

The first corollary: the futurition or the privation of no-thing either absolutely lacks a beginning in time or always was or was eternally. This is clear because futurition and privation are similar things either are something or nothing. If nothing, then they were neither temporally nor eternally. If they are something, then they are either a creator or creature. Not the first, because this is a pure act that is always present. If it is different from God, then it follows that they were not from eternity, as is clear through the first part of the conclusion and its proof. From what has been said it seems to follow that contradictories would not would not be able to be at the same time, that the judgement or the antichrist will be was not able to be true from eternity because it was not from eternity. In the second place it would be able to be inferred that to the negation of things to have eternally existed, it follows that produced something outside of himself eternally. This is clear because, if God eternally produced nothing outside himself, then the negation of nothing thing existed from eternity, which is against
Hugolino, in book two, question two, article four
Hugolinus de Urbe Veteri, II, q. 2, a. 4 (XXX) .

The second principle corollary: not every eternal act of the Father is appropriate or notional. This is clear through the second part of the conclusion because the act by which the Father foreknows some future is common to the three suppositions and as a consequence is not notional.

The third corollary: not every cognitive act of the Father is productive of an infallible Word. This is clear because some act of the Father is productive of no term. This is clear from the act by which he predestined Peter.

The third conclusion: though the paternal memory is fecund with freely and with pleasure, nevertheless the generation of the Word is not properly and formally determined. The first part is clear through the first conclusion. The second part is proved because to be determined properly in this way suggests imperfection, therefore it should not be attributed to the paternal memory. The antecedent is clear because a potency is determined with respect to something, with respect to that act for which it was previously a potency, but this sounds like an imperfection.

The first corollary: just as it is necessary that the Father is enjoying the highest beatitude, so it is necessary that the infallible Word is beget by the same fruition. This is clear because it is just as pleasing to himself in the Word as it is in his very self. Therefore, in
Matthew, chapter 3 , he says:
This is my beloved son Matthaeus 3:17 , etc.

The second corollary: just as it is repugnant to the Father not to be, so it is necessary that he beget. This is clear both because his action is connatural to himself, and also because his action is his being. patet tum quia sua actio est sibi connaturalis tum etiam quia suum agere est suum esse.

The third corollary: though the eternal Word is said by the paternal memory freely, with pleaure, and naturally, nevertheless it is not properly or formally predetermined to do this. This is clear through what has been said, from which the negative part of the conclusion is able to be inferred.

Against the first conclusion it is argued: the eternal Word is not able to be and not be indifferently, therefore it does not produce freely and for its own pleasure. The antecedent is known.
The consequence is clear because only those things are produced freely which are able to be in different ways, or which are able to be and not be.

In the second place, it is argued through the saying of
Richard II De Trinitate, at the end of chapter seven , where he says,
although each one, namely the Father and the Holy Spirit, is from the father, nevertheless each has its own mode of proceeding in one and in the another.
Richardus de Sancto Victore, De Trinitate, II, c. 7 (235, ll.33-37). Cf. III, c. 1 (135, ll. 17-21), and VI, c. 17 (250-252). . But it is certain that, if the Son is produced freely and with pleasure, since the Holy Spirit also proceeds in this way, it would follow that there would not be one mode of proceeding in one and another mode in the other.

In the third place against the third conclusion: there seems to be the position of
Augustine IX De Trinitate, in the last chapter , where he says that
some appetite precedes a part of the mind Augustine, De Trinitate II, c.12, n.18 (CCSL 50, 310, ll. 69-73). . Again, against this, see Item, contra hoc, vide
Scotus, distinction 6 of the first book Scotus, Ordinatio, I, d. 6 (XXX) .

Against the second part of the second conclusion and its corollaries: if there were some eternal non-notional act, it would follow that there would be many gods. This is clear because any eternal act is God himself. Therefore, if there are posited a multitude of eternal acts, it is necessary to posit a multitude of gods, which is nonsense. This is confirmed because in the divine it is the same to know and to understand and to will and so for similar things.

Against the second corollary: the Holy Spirit loves itself by the same love by which the Father and the Son love themselves. But the act of love in the Father and the Son, therefore also in the Holy Spirit. By the same reason, any eternal act of the Father will be notional.

Against the third corollary: if God does something internally through an essential act, then something non-notional is produced internally. The consequence is clear because from active to passion is a good consequence, just as it follows, God creates, therefore something is created. Thus it follows that God acts, therefore something is acted upon.

Against the third conclusion: the paternal memory is not able not to produce the Son, therefore it produces the Son necessarily, therefore not freely. The consequence holds because free and necessary are opposed.

In the second place, it would follow that the will would have the ratio of a principle, as is the case in this kind of generation. The consequent is false because the will would either be following, preceding, or at the same time. Not the first because this was the error of Eunomius who says that it is false that the Son is of an antecedent will as says
Augustine III De Trinitate, in chapter 20 Augustinius, De Trinitate, III, c. 20 (XXX) . Not the second on account of the third corollary of the first conclusion. Not the third because then Son would not be said to be from the Holy Spirit, which is an error.

In the third place against the second corollary: it is just as repugnant that the Father is and is not, as it is that that He does not beget the Son. Therefore this kind of contradiction or repugnance is able to be shown by way of the first principle, and thus it follows that the diversity or plurality of the divine persons would be able to be demonstrated evidently, against what was said above. The first consequence is clear because that the Father is and is not includes a contradiction so formally that such a contradiction is able to be shown evidently from the first principle. Therefore that from the Father does not produce the Son a contradiction follows is able to be shown from the truth of the first principle, which is false.

div.head: Responses
div.p: To the first it is said: that the will concurs in the production of the Word or the will is the productive principle of the Son is able to be understood in an antecedent mode principally, or in another pleasant or delightful mode coexigitively. In this way the principle antecedent is conceded to the argument and the consequence is denied, when taking concurrence of the will in the second mode. But if taken in the first mode, then the entire argument is conceded, and this is not contra to what has been said.

To the second: that is the authority of Ad secundum: quod est auctoritas Richard with
our Doctor Gregory, in book one, distinction six, article two Gregorius Ariminiensis, Lectura, I, d. 6, a. 2 , that there is a single mode of proceeding for each, and the authority of this Doctor in this part should not be believed.
To the third it is said that in this place Augustine speaks about part of our mind, not about the divine mind, as is clearly seen in following text.

To the first against the second conclusion, the consequence is denied. To the proof it is said, regarding the position of
Anselm Monologion, from chapter 62 up to 65, , where he treats this material saying,
dubium esse non debet quod Pater et Filius et eorum unus quisque se ipsum et alios ambos dicit sicut se et alios Anselmus, Monologion, 62 (I, 72, ll. 6-8) ,
he understand that if it is thus, how are there as man words are there sayings in the highest essence? And he adds capitulo 63,
sicut singulus eorum est sciens et intelligens ita singulus quisque dicens, nec tamen omnes simul sunt tres dicentes sed unus solus dicens Anselmus, Monologion, 63 (I, 73, ll. 18-22) . For what is said there except the essence of those things? If therefore there is only one thing, one thing alone is said, therefore if one thing alone is said, then there is also only one thing which says and is said. It follows there that there are not many words. See the place beginning with process.

To the same is the process of
Henry of Ghent, in the first part, article 42 , where he asks,
whether there is no understanding except when the essential part corresponds to the some essential word in God Cf. Henricus de Gandavo, I, a. 40, q. 7 , where he shows that this is not sufficiently explained . For whoever wishes, let him see through this that two other arguments are able to be solved and there is a confirmation of the first.

To the first against the third conclusion: the antecedent and the first consequent are conceded, and the second consequence is denied, and to the proof because liberty is opposed to necessity it is said that this is true about the liberty of coaction and indigence, but it is not opposed to the necessity of pleasure and immutability.

To the second it is able to be said just as it is said to the first argument against the first conclusion because, if it is understood that the will produces the Son antecedently principative, then the consequent and the consequence is denied. If indeed with pleasure and coexigitive, then the consequent is able to be conceded. And it is said further to the arguments against that it is produced by a coeval will, and when it is inferred that therefore the Son is not distinct from the Holy Spirit, the consequence is denied when understanding the will or to produce voluntarily uniformly.

To the third, the consequence is denied because, though one is just as repugnant as the other, nevertheless that one is a contradiction which does not stand and nor does it appear to us just as the other. Therefore it does not follow that, if one repugnance is able to be demonstrated to us by the truth of the first principle, that also the other is able to be shown to us evidently.

To the arguments in opposition, it is clear from what has been said how the will concurs in the generation of the Son. Again, it is clear why paternal memory is not properly determined, as the arguments proved, although it is perhaps able to be said to be determined when speaking improperly.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p:
Praeterea Hic
Gracilis appears to make a mistake here in the citation of this incipit. The incipit of d. 6 reads, as stated at the outset of this question, "praeterea quaeri solet". This incipit stated here actually mirrors the incipit of distinction 7, c. 1. This similarity of the incipits likely accounts for the accidental reference to distinction 7, when actually referring to distinction 6.
quaeri solet
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 6, c. 1 (I, 89, ll. 4).
. This distinction contains three conclusions. First that just as God the Father is God neither by necessity or by will, neither by not-willing or willing, so God the Father beget the Son neither by necessity or by will, he begin him neither by not-willing or willing, contrary to the understanding of the heretic.

The second conclusion that, though in God nature and will are the same thing, nevertheless it does not follow that, if the Word of God is the Son by nature, that on account of this he is the Son by will, just as it does not follows that the foreknowledge and the divine will are the same, therefore whatever is said about one is said about the other. For foreknowledge is about the good and the bad, but the will is truly only about the good or with respect to the good.

Third conclusion that the Father begat the Son willingly just as he was able, and the good begat him and also wisdom, nevertheless not by a preceding or following will, nor did he beget the Son by a necessitated natural coactions or leading. And therefore not by unwillingly, but willingly he generated him, namely by an approving will and pleasing will, as was said about, etc.
